data.title: Type definitions missing in plain JavaScript
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

After updating Visual Studio Code to 1.14.1, I can't seem to use type definitions on JavaScript projects.

In this example below, previously I can simply use `Knex` class without further configuration after installing the package through `npm`.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2698543/28304780-5da53cbc-6bc3-11e7-943b-612dc31618e3.png)

Also, it seems that type detections from packages are missing. Previously VSCode can detect the return type from functions in npm packages; now it can't.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2698543/28305234-1626d7ae-6bc5-11e7-8d32-df71f5fc0ac3.png)

However, functions returning standard JavaScript types are still shown properly.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2698543/28305538-2d0692a6-6bc6-11e7-8545-ff6eb8e0d358.png)

My project is a "plain standard" npm project (no TypeScript), with `package.json` present and all modules installed in `node_modules`.

Is this a bug or there are new changes? If there are new changes, is there any configurations or plugins required to get the type definitions back?

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Update to 1.14.1
2. Open a JavaScript project directory containing a npm package.
3. Attempt to use the type in IntelliSense, or look at definitions from a package function.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Unnecessarily high CPU usage for cursor blinking
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:12:01.887Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.10.0-19-generic
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file, and put the cursor anywhere.
2. Watch CPU usage while the cursor blinks
3. The cursor stops blinking after ~10 seconds, notice how the CPU usage lowered by ~15%
4. Move the cursor again, it starts blinking, and CPU usage goes up again by ~15%.

I use the `phased` cursor blink setting.

data.title: can not debug cluster.fork code
Node.js debug causes tons of lag in editor - high CPU/Memory
data.body:
- VSCode Version: I reproduced this issue with the latest Insiders build and regular build, but the issue does not occur when using 1.13.1.
- OS Version: Windows 8.1
- Node Version: 6.10.0 (64-bit)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. F5 to start my app.
2. Navigate to any page. Refresh it quickly a few times. Notice that CPU of VSCode goes up to 12-ish percent. Memory starts climbing. Editor becomes mostly unresponsive...can't even click on the "stop debugging" button or move my cursor. After 10-30 seconds, CPU goes back to 0%, and VSCode becomes responsive again.

When I tried this in 1.13.1, the CPU never goes higher than 1% and stays at 0% most of the time. 

I tried using typescript 2.3.4 just in case my issue was typescript related (even though my project doesn't have any typescript), and that didn't make a difference.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Missing a MRU list in search & replace tab
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

It would be really nice to have a simple mru list for the latest searches. Sometimes when refactoring or navigating through code I need multiple searches.     at Module._compile (module.js:571:32)

data.title: Editor hangs after folder search
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58)
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VSCode in a project folder
2. Search project for a simple string (no regex, excludes, includes, etc.)
3. Editor begins to slow down, cpu usage goes up, and VSCode eventually hangs
4. Before the editor begins to hang, the search panel has a continuous "loading" state that never stops
![vscode-search](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2320890/28292869-0c2d07b0-6b06-11e7-8459-f9e2933b2233.gif)

Also, after the first search usage, the quick file selector starts lagging behind as well.


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

If someone could give me pointers on how to debug or profile what might be going on in the editor/search service, I'd be happy to dig more.

data.title: Code hangs when trying to open C# File
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

I have a CSharp file that will cause Code to become unresponsive every time it is opened. I've tried to narrow it down to what about the file causes it, but it doesn't seem to be a single line, nor consistent. I've uninstalled all the extensions, tried running with --disable-extensions, and closing the active folder. I've also run code with --verbose, but it doesn't report anything after the arg display other than:

[main 3:02:30 PM] IPC#vscode-machineId
[main 3:02:30 PM] IPC#vscode-workbenchLoaded
[VS Code]: detected unresponsive 

I'd be happy to email the file to one of the devs, but don't want to post on the open Internet.

R

- OS Version: OS X 10.12.5

data.title: Feature Request: Propose undefined method names as autocomplete suggestions
data.body:
Especially during UI coding, I repeatedly find myself in the following situation:

    ....
    <button onClick={this.handleClick} />

and `this.handleClick` is undefined. Next, I place the cursor in the class, and type...

    private handleClick(e: MouseEvent) {
    }

It would be super useful if `handleClick` would be offered as auto-complete suggestion by VSCode in this situation. In general, any undefined symbol name could be offered as a completion option when typing a new method. There's a pretty good chance in general that the name of a method-under-construction already appears as an undefined symbol somewhere else in the class. I don't know how technically challenging this feature would be, but it sure would come in handy.

data.title: Test new markdown preview security settings
data.body:
**Size**: 3

**OS**
- [x] Linux @roblourens 
- [x] Mac @rebornix 
- [x] Windows @ramya-rao-a 


# Overview
The July update tweaks the markdown preview security settings to disable loading insecure content by default and allow for finer control over what content is loaded. The new security settings have three levels:

- Strict â€” Disables http content, svgs, and other potentially dangerous elements such a scripts
-  Allow insecure content â€” Allow http content and svgs but keep scripts disabled
- None â€” Anything goes

# Tests
**Basic**
  1. Create a new workspace and crate a markdown document with the following content:
  
```markdown 
Https cat is very friendly and should always be around:

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Silverton_-_Domestic_Cat.JPG/320px-Silverton_-_Domestic_Cat.JPG)

Http cat is a bit more skittish and should only show up when you select `allow insecure content`:

![](http://www.petdrugsonline.co.uk/images/page-headers/cats-master-header)

Script kitty should only show up in the background when you disable security:

<script>
document.body.style.background = 'url(http://everywhereagency.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/keyboard.png)'
</script>

Vector cat should only show up when you allow insecure content:

 ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/60/Cat_silhouette.svg)
```

2. Open the markdown preview. 
3. Make sure the correct cats are showing. When some content has not been loaded, there should be an alert in the markdown preview. Click on this alert to change security settings for previews in this workspace


**Local resources**
1. Also try adding some local images:

```markdown
![](local/cat.png)
```

Local images should always be loaded

**Security settings apply per workspace**
1. Now try creating multiple markdown documents and opening previews for them.
2. Make sure the markdown security setting applies to all markdown files in the workspace.
3. Close and reopen vscode and make sure the security setting is persisted
4. Open multiple workspaces. Make sure the settings work as expected in this scenario

**Run the `Change Markdown preview security settings` command**
1. With only a markdown document open (and no previews) run the `Change Markdown preview security settings` command
2. Make sure this setting correctly applies when you open a preview

data.title: Screen doesn't follow cursor beyond screen's edge when using multiple cursors
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: OSX Sierra 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Drop multiple cursors
2. Move the cursor to a place beyond the edge of the screen
3. content wont move with cursor, basically hiding the cursor.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes
![untitled2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11534188/28283580-c2d0423a-6b4b-11e7-8fbb-765b59a28c3a.gif)

data.title: Login with an account and sync setting/plugin
data.body:
Login with an account and sync setting/plugin.
Can we do it like chrome?
